journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Analytical modeling of combustion of a single iron particle burning in the gaseous oxidizing medium

article-meta.aff: Combustion Research Laboratory, School of Mechanical Engineering, Iran University of Science & Technology (IUST), Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Majid Mafi, School of Mechanical Engineering, Iran University of Science & Technology, Narmak, Tehran 16846-13114, Iran. Email: majid.mafi@gmail.com

abstract.p: In the present study, a theoretical investigation is accomplished to model the combustion of a single iron particle by virtue of a novel thermophysical approach. It is assumed that a spherical iron particle falls freely in the gaseous medium and preheats and then burns heterogeneously on its external surface in this hot oxidizing environment and oxygen diffuses inward to the particle. A new physical parameter for thermal radiation is introduced. By solving the energy conservation equation for the iron particle, the temperature distribution of the iron particle during the preheating and combustion processes is calculated analytically. Also, by solving the oxygen mass conservation equation, the variation of oxygen concentration within the iron particle during the combustion stage is estimated. In the proposed model, the effect of thermal radiation and dynamic behavior of burning iron particle are considered. Because of high thermal conductivity and micro size of iron particle, the Biot number is negligibly small. The non-homogeneous partial differential equations of energy and mass species resulted from the modeling of combustion are solved by utilizing the method of separation of variables. The assumptions applied in the modeling are such that do not violate the actual combustion phenomenon. Also, the numerical solution of energy equation in the combustion stage is presented and compared with the obtained analytical solution. Also, the burnout time of iron particle is evaluated in this article. This investigation is one of the first performed efforts for analyzing and modeling of single iron particle combustion.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Combustion of metallic substances is an interesting scientific topic that also has significant practical applications. Since the combustion of metallic particles is a high exothermic chemical reaction, use of them in the industrial operations is significant and efficient. The virtue of metals as fuels is enhanced by their relatively high density, flame temperature and heat of combustion. They are easy to handle and store, inexpensive and readily available. Combustion of iron particle cloud experimentally investigated in some works. Iron is regarded as a non-volatile metallic fuel and the oxidation process takes place as a heterogeneous surface reaction. The major characteristic feature of iron combustion is that iron burns heterogeneously in air. It means that combustion reaction occurs at the iron particle surface and no flame is observed in the gaseous oxidizer phase. Iron particles do not evaporate during the combustion process and also combustion product (iron oxide) remains in the condensed phase. Because of high energy density of iron, the combustion of iron can be used as an alternative fuel in automobile engines and solid propellant rocket motors in the future. Recently, Bidabadi et al.1 presented a mathematical modeling for temperature profile and flame speed across the combustion zones propagating through iron dust clouds. Bidabadi et al.2 analytically investigated the dynamic behavior of particles across flame propagation through micro-iron dust cloud with thermal radiation effect. Also, Bidabadi et al.3 theoretically studied the distribution of iron dust particles through unburned zone across the flame propagation in a vertical duct by using homotopy analysis method. Also, Bidabadi et al.4 theoretically proposed a mathematical modeling of velocity and number density profiles of particles across the flame propagation through a micro-iron dust cloud. All three studies focused on the dynamic behavior of iron particle clouds and various forces exerted on the particles in the preheat zone, prior to the flame zone. In addition, Bidabadi et al. studied the combustion of various type of particle cloud in several works.5–15 Furthermore, Tang et al.16 experimentally performed the so-called argon/helium test to determine the modes of particle combustion in iron dust flames. Experiments were accomplished in a reduced-gravity environment. Also, Tang et al.17 experimentally studied the quenching and laminar flames propagating in fuel-rich suspension of iron dust in air in a reduced-gravity environment provided by a parabolic flight aircraft. Moreover, Sun et al.18 measured the particle velocity and particle number density profiles across upward and downward flame propagating through iron particle clouds by using the high-speed photomicrographs. Sun et al.19 experimentally examined the concentration profile of particles across a flame propagating through an iron particle cloud. Sun et al.20 experimentally evaluated the temperature profile across the combustion zone propagating through an iron particle cloud. Also, Sun et al.21 experimentally investigated the combustion behavior of iron particles suspended in air. In addition, Steinberg et al.22–33 has carried out many experiments on the burning iron rods.

Similar studies have been carried out with many particles. Boron particle combustion in which oxygen penetrates to the particle both by diffusion and dissolving has been studied.34,35 Also, one of the most important solid fuels is coal, which is typically burned as a pulverized powder in utility boilers. Combustion of coal, char, and carbon has been investigated in many researches.36–40
In the previous works, combustion of iron cloud has been experimentally investigated, or the dynamic behavior of iron particle in preheat zone has been studied.

Equilibrium thermodynamic calculation estimates a stoichiometric adiabatic flame temperature of iron in air of 2250 K which is well below the boiling point temperature of iron at atmospheric pressure that is 3130 K.17 Thus, it is proved that iron burns as a pure heterogeneous flame in air.

This article proposed a novel analytical approach to model the combustion of single iron particle burning in the gaseous oxidizing medium. By using this model, the variation of iron particle temperature during the preheating and combustion processes as a function of time and radial coordinate can be obtained. Furthermore, oxygen concentration profile within the iron particle as a function of time and radial position can be determined. This model includes the thermal radiation effect.

This model applied for the combustion of iron particle for the first time, and can be improved in the future studies to include more complicated parameters that influence the circumstance of combustion. Because of linearity and homogeneity of the governing differential equations along the radial coordinate, the separation of variables method is utilized for solving the energy equation and mass species conservation of oxygen in the iron particle.

sec.title: Modeling of iron particle combustion
sec.p: Assuming a single micro-sized spherical iron particle burns heterogeneously in the gaseous oxidizer environment. Furthermore, iron particle falls freely during its combustion. In the first stage, iron particle is heated up by convection mechanism and its temperature is raised from initial temperature to its ignition temperature. Once the iron particle reaches to its ignition temperature, the burning process is started. Henceforward, iron reacts with oxygen at the high temperature condition. This stage is the combustion of iron particle. At this stage, oxygen adsorbs to the particle surface and dissociates to the oxygen radicals and diffuses into the particle. Due to the heat liberated by combustion, the iron particle temperature increases. The combustion phenomenon continues until the particle burning time is finished. Then, the combustion is stopped and particle begins to cool down by convection and radiation.

The assumptions used in this modeling are:
The spherical iron particle burns in a quiescent, infinite ambient medium that contains only oxygen and an inert gas, such as nitrogen. There are no interactions with other particles, and the effects of disturbances are ignored.
Constant thermophysical properties for the iron particle and ambient gaseous oxidizer are used.
The shape of particle and boundary conditions are spherically symmetric and the particle temperature and oxygen concentration inside the particle vary only along the radial coordinate.
Oxygen atoms diffuse into the iron particle and react with iron heterogeneously and heat of combustion is released in the particle.
The surface reaction rate is very fast compared to the oxidizer diffusion rate.
Because of spherical symmetry, the governing equations of conservation mass species and energy are one-dimensional partial differential equations. It means that the temperature and concentration of oxygen within the burning iron particle depend on radial coordinate and time only.
The iron particle falls freely in the stagnant gaseous oxidizing medium with the terminal velocity due to the gravity.
The burning process is unsteady.

sec.title: Pre-ignition stage
sec.p: The partial differential equation that governs the variation of temperature in the iron particle in this stage is obtained from the following equation (1)λp(∂2T∂r2+2r∂T∂r)=ρpcp∂T∂t where λp is the thermal conductivity of iron particle, ρp is the density of iron particle, cp is the specific heat capacity of iron particle, T is the particle temperature, r is the radial coordinate, and t is the time. The initial condition can be expresses as (2)T(r,0)=Ti The boundary conditions can be expressed as (3)B.Cs.:{∂T(r,t)∂r|r=0=∂T(0,t)∂r=0-[-λp∂T(r,t)∂r|r=rp]=h¯conv[T∞-T(rp,t)]+ɛpσ[Tsurr4-T4(rp,t)] where rp is the radius of the iron particle, Ts=T(rp,t) is the surface temperature of iron particle, h¯conv is the average convective heat transfer coefficient, T∞ is ambient temperature, Tsurr is surrounding temperature which is assumed to be equal to ambient temperature (Tsurr=T∞), ɛp is the emissivity of the iron particle surface, σ=5.67×10-8W/m2K4 is the Stefan–Boltzmann constant.
The pseudo-radiative heat transfer coefficient is defined as (4)hrad=ɛpσ[Ts+T∞][Ts2+T∞2]

Accounting for the variation of the pseudo-radiative heat transfer coefficient with temperature, in general, complicates the analysis due to the non-linearity. Therefore, the average pseudo-radiative heat transfer coefficient can be introduced which is the average value of pseudo-radiative heat transfer coefficient in the temperature range Ti to Tig in the preheating process and can be determined from (5)h¯rad=(1Tig-Ti)∫TiTighrad(Ts)dTsh¯rad=(1Tig-Ti)∫TiTigɛpσ[Ts+T∞][Ts2+T∞2]dTsh¯rad=(ɛpσTig-Ti)[Tig4-Ti44+T∞(Tig3-Ti3)3 +T∞2(Tig2-Ti2)2+T∞3(Tig-Ti)1] The combined heat transfer coefficient, h¯combined, is obtained as following equation (6)h¯combined=h¯conv+h¯rad where h¯conv is the average convective heat transfer coefficient and h¯rad is the average pseudo-radiative heat transfer coefficient. Note that the combined heat transfer coefficient is essentially a convective heat transfer coefficient modified to include the effect of thermal radiation. Based upon this definition, the second boundary condition can be rewritten as (7)-λp∂T(r,t)∂r|r=rp=h¯combined[T(rp,t)-T∞]

To non-dimensionalize the problem, dimensionless space variable ξ and dimensionless temperature θ are defined. Both ξ and θ vary between 0 and 1. The proper form of the dimensionless time is τ, which is called the Fourier number Fo, and the dimensionless form of convective heat transfer coefficient is the Biot number BiH. The dimensionless quantities introduced in the formulation are (8)θ=T(r,t)-T∞Tig-T∞, ξ=rrp,τ=Fo=αptrp2, BiH=h¯combinedrpλp where αp is the thermal diffusivity of iron, i.e. αp=λp/ρpcp. By using of these dimensionless variables, the partial differential equation reduces to the non-dimensionalized form as (9)1ξ2∂∂ξ(ξ2∂θ∂ξ)=∂θ∂τ
The solution of this PDE is θ=θ(ξ,τ). Also, the non-dimensionless initial condition and boundary conditions can be expressed as (10){θ(ξ,0)=1∂θ(ξ,τ)∂ξ|ξ=0=∂θ(0,τ)∂ξ=0-∂θ(ξ,τ)∂ξ|ξ=1=BiHθ(1,τ)

Therefore, the dimensionless temperature distribution is given by (11)θ(ξ,τ)= 4BiH∑n=1∞[sinμnμn(2μn-sin2μn)]exp(-μn2τ)(sin(μnξ)ξ) where the eigenvalues μn are the roots of the transcendental characteristic equation given by equation (12). The first eight roots of equation (12) for BiH=0.0046 are given in Table 1. (12)μncotμn=1-BiH n=1,2,3,… Table 1.
The roots of characteristic equations, equations (12) and (25).
BiH=0.0046 (Preheating stage) BiH=0.0050 (Combustion stage)
n μn n μn
1 0.117419 1 0.122413
2 4.49443 2 4.49452
3 7.72585 3 7.72590
4 10.9045 4 10.9046
5 14.0665 5 14.0665
6 17.2210 6 17.2210
7 20.3715 7 20.3715
8 23.5196 8 23.5196

sec.title: The combustion process
sec.p: In combustion analysis, conversion process of chemical energy into heat (or thermal energy) is characterized as heat generation. In the combustion phenomenon, source of heat generation in a medium is exothermic chemical reaction that may occur throughout the medium. Note that heat generation is a volumetric phenomenon. Therefore, the rate of heat generation in a medium is usually specified per unit volume and is denoted by q·gen″'. This stage begins at the ignition temperature. For modeling of this stage, consider a spherical iron particle of radius rp is initially at an ignition temperature of Tig. At t=0, energy is generated interior the spherical iron particle due to the heterogeneous oxidation reaction at a nearly uniform rate of q·gen″' (W/m3). (13)q·gen″'=(ℜ·FeLc)Δ hcomb∘ where ℜ·Fe (kg/m2s) is the mass reaction rate of iron, Lc (m) is the characteristic length of spherical iron particle, and Δ hcomb∘ (kJ/kg) is the heat of combustion or enthalpy of combustion of iron. Characteristic length of spherical iron is expressed as (14)Lc=VpAs=43πrp34πrp2=rp3 where Vp (m3) is the volume of the iron particle, and As (m2) is the surface area of iron particle. Therefore, volumetric heat generation within particle due to combustion can be expressed as (15)q·gen″'=(Asℜ·FeVp)Δ hcomb∘=(3ℜ·Ferp)Δ hcomb∘

Mass reaction rate of iron is experimentally obtained as25 (16)ℜ·Fe=-7.05×103 exp(-2.9684×104T)PO212 (grcm2·s) where T is the temperature of the burning iron particle and PO2 is the partial pressure of oxygen in the oxidizing environment. The governing differential equation for temperature is obtained as (17)λpr2∂∂r(r2∂T∂r)+q·gen″'=ρpcp∂T∂t

The initial and boundary conditions associated with equation (17) are (18){T(r,0)=Tig∂T(r,t)∂r|r=0=∂T(0,t)∂r=0-λp∂T(r,t)∂r|r=rp=h¯combined[T(rp,t)-T∞] where (19)h¯combined=h¯conv+h¯rad where h¯rad is the average pseudo-radiative heat transfer coefficient in the combustion process which can be evaluated by integrating the pseudo-radiative heat transfer coefficient in the temperature range Tig to Tfin in the combustion stage (20)h¯rad=(1Tfin-Tig)∫TigTfinhrad(Ts)dTsh¯rad=(1Tfin-Tig)∫TigTfinɛpσ[Ts+T∞][Ts2+T∞2]dTsh¯rad=(ɛpσTfin-Tig)[Tfin4-Tig44+T∞(Tfin3-Tig3)3+T∞2(Tfin2-Tig2)2+T∞3(Tfin-Tig)1] where Tfin is the final temperature of iron particle in the combustion process.

Introduction of the dimensionless quantities (21)θ=T(r,t)-T∞Tig-T∞, ξ=rrp, τ=Fo=αptrp2Ψ=q·gen″'rp2λp(Tig-T∞), BiH=h¯combinedrpλp reduces equations (17) and (18) to (22)1ξ2∂∂ξ(ξ2∂θ∂ξ)+Ψ=∂θ∂τ (23){θ(ξ,0)=1∂θ(ξ,τ)∂ξ|ξ=0=∂θ(0,τ)∂ξ=0-∂θ(ξ,τ)∂ξ|ξ=1=BiHθ(1,τ) Since equation (22) is not homogeneous, the problem can be split up into two simpler problems each involving only one non-homogeneous term, and then combining the solutions by superposition. The dimensionless temperature distribution of the iron particle in the combustion stage is given by (24)θ(ξ,τ)=[Ψ6(1-ξ2)+Ψ3BiH] -{2BiH∑n=1∞(Ψμn2-1)[cosμnμn(1-BiH-cos2μn)] ×exp(-μn2τ)(sin(μnξ)ξ)} where the eigenvalues μn are the roots of the following characteristic equation (25)μncotμn=1-BiH n=1,2,3,…
This characteristic equation is identical to equation (12) by different BiH number value. The first eight roots of equation (25) for BiH=0.0050 are given in Table 1.

sec.title: Oxygen mass conservation equation
sec.p: The spherical iron particle Fe of radius rp is oxygen-free at the beginning of the combustion circumstance. Iron particle is surrounded by oxidizing gas. As species O2 adsorbs to the iron particle surface, it is dissociated to the O atoms and then these oxygen atoms diffuse into Fe, it undergoes an irreversible heterogeneous chemical reaction with Fe to form FeO.

Wustite (Fe0.95O will be treated as FeO), magnetite (Fe3O4) and hematite (Fe2O3) are the standard oxides of cold burning of iron. In fact, wustite is formed at the stoichiometric condition. If there is a lot of excess oxygen in the burning iron particle, wustite can react with oxygen and form other iron oxide component, like magnetite or hematite. Formation of other iron oxides depends upon oxygen concentration and temperature. Between 973 K and 1473 K, iron readily oxidizes either in air or oxygen to give a sequence of three layers. The inner layer, Fe1-δO wustite (as FeO) occupies about 0.95 of the thickness, the intermediate layer is magnetite, Fe3O4, which occupies about 0.045 of the thickness, and the outer layer is hematite, Fe2O3, which is the remaining 0.005 of the thickness.25 The iron oxide shell formed on the micro-sized iron particle has a layered structure. It is built up by FeO (located at the phase boundary to Fe), Fe3O4 and Fe2O3 (at higher concentration of oxygen) toward the outer surface of the particle, respectively.

The molar rate of reaction of oxygen with iron ω·O2 is a function of concentration and is expressed by (26)ω·O2=k(T)CO2 where CO2 is the concentration of oxygen within the iron particle, and k=k(T) is the specific reaction-rate coefficient or the temperature-dependent rate coefficient.
The governing differential equation for the concentration of species O2 is given as (27)DO2-Fer2∂∂r(r2∂CO2∂r)-ω·O2=∂CO2∂t where DO2-Fe is the mass diffusivity of oxygen in iron particle.

The initial and the boundary conditions associated with equation (27) are (28)I.C.:{CO2(r,0)=0B.Cs.:{∂CO2(0,t)∂r=0CO2(rp,t)=CO2* Where CO2* is the equilibrium solubility of oxygen in the iron particle.

The partial differential equation (27) is solved by using of method of separation of variables and the general solution is obtained as (29)CO2(r,t)CO2*=1-(2rpπr)∑n=1∞(-1)n+1n ×{1+Ωexp[-(1+Ω)kt]1+Ω}sin(nπrrp) where (30)Ω=n2π2DO2-Fekrp2

sec.title: Dynamics of a single iron particle and convective heat transfer coefficient
sec.p: It is assumed that the iron particle is dropped into the air; it falls due to the gravity. During this free fall, iron particle reaches its terminal velocity which is the maximum velocity that a free falling particle can attain when all the forces balance each other and the net force acting on the particle (and thus its acceleration) is zero. The forces exerted on the falling particle are usually the weight of the particle, the buoyant force, and the drag force. At terminal velocity the particle will not be accelerating so the forces acting on the free falling particle are at the equilibrium, i.e. the weight of the particle equals the buoyant force plus the drag force. The particle terminal velocity can be estimated as follows (31)W=FB+FD43πρpgrp3=43πρ∞grp3+12CDρ∞AprVterm2Vterm=8π(ρp-ρ∞)grp33CDρ∞Apr Where W is the weight of iron particle, FB is buoyant force, FD is drag force, g is gravitational acceleration, ρ∞ is density of gaseous medium, CD is drag coefficient, Apr is projected area of particle perpendicular to the direction of falling, Vterm is terminal velocity of falling iron particle.

Assuming the iron particle falls and burns in the quiescent medium and the relative velocity between particle and ambient gas is very small. At low Reynolds numbers (Rep<1), the drag coefficient for a spherical particle is given by CD=24Rep=24(ρ∞Vpdpμ∞)=24μ∞ρ∞Vtermdp<label>(32)</label> Therefore Vterm=2grp2(ρp-ρ∞)9μ∞<label>(33)</label>

In the case of particle falling in the motionless oxidizer medium, the average convective heat transfer coefficient on the particle surface can be obtained by a relation for the Nusselt number for low Reynolds number flow42 (34)Nu¯=h¯convdpλ∞=2+Pe+Pe2lnPe+f(Pr∞)Pe2: Rep <<1, Pr∞ ~1 where Nu¯ is the average Nusselt number for iron particle, h¯conv is the convective heat transfer coefficient, dp is the diameter of the iron particle, λ∞ is the thermal conductivity of the gaseous oxidizing environment, Pe=RepPr∞ is the Peclet number, Pr∞ is the Prandtl number of ambient gaseous oxidizing medium, and (35)f(Pr∞)=12[(2Pr∞2-Pr∞-4γ-21340)+2(Pr∞3-3Pr∞-2)lnPr∞-2(Pr∞+1)2(Pr∞-2)ln(Pr∞+1)] where γ=0.5772156… is the Euler number. Prandtl number of ambient gas is defined as Pr∞=μ∞cp,∞λ∞<label>(36)</label> where cp,∞ is specific heat capacity at constant pressure of ambient gaseous fluid. Moreover, it is assumed that the Biot number for the burning iron particle is a negligible value, because of the high thermal conductivity of iron particle and small diameter of the particle (BiH=(h¯combineddp/λp) <<0.1). Hence, the lumped system analysis can be applied for iron particle combustion, and it means that the temperature of the iron particle is a function of time only and not a function of location in the particle (T=T(t)).

sec.title: Burning time of a single iron particle
sec.p: On the other hand, the mode of combustion of micro sized iron particle is diffusionally controlled regime, and diffusion of oxygen in iron particle is a slower phenomenon. Iron burns in oxygen as heterogeneous combustion.

The burning time of iron particles in diffusionally controlled regime can be obtained from the following relation43 (37)tbdiff=ρpdp,028ρ∞DO2-∞ln(1+νYO2,∞) where tbdiff is the burning time of iron particle in diffusionally controlled regime, ρp is the iron particle density, dp,0 is the initial diameter of the iron particle, ρ∞ is the ambient gas density, DO2-∞ is the diffusivity of oxygen in the ambient gas, ν is the ratio of mass stoichiometric coefficient of iron to oxidizer in the chemical reaction formula, and YO2,∞ is the mass fraction of oxygen in the ambient gas far from the particle surface.

The chemical reaction formula of combustion of iron at stoichiometric condition is expressed as (38){nFeFe+nO2O2→nFeOFeOmFeFe+mO2O2→mFeOFeO where (39){mFe=nFeMFemO2=nO2MO2mFeO=nFeOMFeO where nFe is molar stoichiometric coefficient of iron in chemical reaction formula, nO2 is molar stoichiometric coefficient of oxygen in chemical reaction formula, nFeO is molar stoichiometric coefficient of iron oxide in chemical reaction formula, MFe is atomic weight of iron, MO2 is molecular weight of oxygen, MFeO is molecular weight of iron oxide, mFe is mass stoichiometric coefficient of iron in chemical reaction formula, mO2 is mass stoichiometric coefficient of oxygen in chemical reaction formula, mFeO is mass stoichiometric coefficient of iron oxide in chemical reaction formula. Dividing the mass stoichiometric coefficients in the chemical reaction formula to the mass stoichiometric coefficient of iron changes the form of chemical reaction formula of combustion of iron to (40)Fe+νO2→(1+ν)FeO where ν is mass stoichiometric index which is defined as (41)ν=(mO2mFe)sto
For combustion of iron, the chemical formula can be written as (42){(2 kmol) Fe+(1 kmol)O2→(2 kmol) FeO(111.69 kg) Fe+(31.99 kg) O2→(143.68 kg) FeO
Mass stoichiometric index, ν, for iron combustion equals ν=(31.99kg)O2(111.69kg)Fe=0.2864.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
In this section, the diagrams of temperature of iron particle as a function of time and radial coordinate, the plots of the oxygen concentration within the particle as a function of time and radial position and burning time of particle are plotted. The thermophysical properties used in the calculations for iron particle with the diameter of 20 µm is listed in Table 2. Also, the mean values of the calculated physical parameters for the various particle diameters are summarized in the Table 3. The expanded uncertainty estimates of calculated parameters are listed in Table 4. The value of parameter X can be expressed as, Xtrue=Xmean±UX. For example, the burning time of 20 µm iron particle is 0.0075±0.0011. Figure 1 shows the variation of dimensionless temperature of iron particle as a function of dimensionless time and dimensionless radial position for an iron particle with the diameter of 20 µm in the heating process. The variation of absolute temperature of iron particle as a function of time and radial coordinate for an iron particle with the diameter of 20 µm in the heating process is illustrated in Figure 2. The variation of dimensionless temperature of iron particle as a function of dimensionless time and dimensionless radial position for an iron particle with the diameter of 20 µm in the combustion stage is shown in Figure 3. The variation of absolute temperature of iron particle as a function of time and radial coordinate for an iron particle with the diameter of 20 µm in the combustion stage is plotted in Figure 4. For comparison of results, the numerical solution of the energy differential equation in the combustion stage defined in equation (20) associated with initial and boundary conditions defined in equation (21) for iron particle with the diameter of 20 µm is sketched in Figure 5. The surface temperature of iron particle versus time from the initial temperature to the maximum final temperature in the heating and combustion stages is illustrated in Figure 6. Figure 1.
The variation of dimensionless temperature of iron particle as a function of dimensionless time and dimensionless radial position for an iron particle with the diameter of 20 µm in the preheating stage.
Figure 2.
The variation of absolute temperature of iron particle as a function of time and radial position for an iron particle with the diameter of 20 µm in the preheating stage.
Figure 3.

Figure 4.

Figure 5.
The numerical solution of the energy differential equation in the combustion stage.
Figure 6.
The surface temperature of iron particle versus time from the initial temperature to the maximum temperature in the heating and combustion stages.

The variation of oxygen concentration within the iron particle as a function of time and radial coordinate for an iron particle with the diameter of 20 µm is depicted in Figure 7. The variation of oxygen concentration inside the iron particle as a function of radial distance at various times from the ignition until the burning time for an iron particle with the diameter of 20 µm is sketched in Figure 8. Figure 7.
The variation of oxygen concentration within the iron particle as a function of time and radial coordinate for an iron particle with the diameter of 20 µm.
Figure 8.
The variation of oxygen concentration inside the iron particle as a function of radial coordinate at various times from the ignition until the burning time for an iron particle with the diameter of 20 µm.

The convective heat transfer coefficient as a function of iron particle diameter is sketched in Figure 9. The burning time of micro-sized spherical iron particles as a function of particle diameter is represented in Figure 10. As observed in this figure, the analytical burning time obtained in this study is approximately close to the experimental burning time presented in a published paper for micro-sized iron particles.21 However, the values of burning time estimated by analysis are slightly lower than that of burning time predicted by experiment. The full-logarithmic chart of iron burning time as a function of particle diameter is shown in Figure 11. Figure 12 demonstrates that particle burning time decreases as ambient temperature (air temperature) raises. Figure 9.
The convective heat transfer coefficient as a function of iron particle diameter.
Figure 10.
The burning time of micro-sized spherical iron particle as a function of particle diameter burning in air.
Figure 11.
Logarithmic chart of burning time of spherical iron particle as a function of particle diameter burning in air at atmospheric pressure and 1000 K.
Figure 12.
Burning time of spherical iron particle as a function of ambient temperature for particle with diameter of 20 µm burning in air at atmospheric pressure.

It is observed that the temperature increases in the combustion stage due to the heat generation of combustion within particle. This increase in temperature of iron particle occurs during the burning time of iron particle. The figures indicate that the temperature of iron particle reaches to the maximum value at the end of the burning time. After the temperature reaches to its highest value, the chemical reaction finishes and heat generation inside the particle vanishes. The figures reveal that the temperature variation within the particle is not noticeable and temperature varies slightly from the midpoint of the particle to the particle surface because the Biot number for the iron particle is a negligibly small value. On the other hand, distribution of oxygen concentration from the ignition time until the burning time varies substantially. Oxygen molecules adsorb to the particle surface and then diffuse into the particle and react with iron and consume. At the end of the combustion stage, oxygen concentration interior the iron particle approaches to the oxygen concentration on the particle surface. The iron particle surface is saturated by the oxygen molecules.

Although, there is no available experimental study that presents the temperature of single iron particle during its combustion, but also, there are several experimental studies that demonstrate the temperature of iron clouds. By comparison to the experimental data, it is observed that the maximum temperature of iron particle obtained from presented theoretical model is in good agreement with the adiabatic flame temperature of iron in air (2250 K). It is noted that the particle temperature must be always greater than that of the air in the combustion zone. Because, heat is generated in the particle due to chemical reaction and then, heat is transferred to the ambient air. Also, the numerical result is adequately close to the analytical result obtained from the method of the separation of variables that indicates the mathematical method for solving the governing partial differential equations of combustion of single iron particle is efficient and accurate.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: It is deduced from the analytical results that for the spherical iron particle falling and burning in the gaseous oxidizer, in the preheating process the temperature of the iron particle increases from the initial temperature to the ignition temperature asymptotically. Once the particle surface ignited, the combustion process is started and particle begins to burn. In this stage, the particle temperature raises from the ignition temperature to the final maximum temperature at the burnout time. In this circumstance, oxygen molecules are adsorbed to the iron particle surface and then diffuse inward in the particle. The concentration distribution of oxygen within the iron particle increases during the combustion process and that approaches to the saturated equilibrium concentration on the surface.

The analytical solution obtained from the separation of variables method is verified with the numerical solution of the energy equation of the iron particle in the combustion stage. Obviously, the analytical and numerical results are satisfactorily identical to each other, as depicted in Figure 5. It indicates that the mathematical solving technique for combustion modeling of iron particle is efficiently acceptable.

The significance of thermal radiation in the total heat loss from the particle surface compared to that of convection is smaller. Because of high convective heat transfer coefficient the dominant mechanism of heat loss to the environment is the convection and contribution of thermal radiation in the total heat loss from the particle surface to the environment in the combustion stage is 12%. In the energy analysis of combustion, a novel thermophysical parameter for thermal radiation in a large interval of temperature in the combustion problems is introduced. The complexity of considering of thermal radiation effect in solving of energy equation is facilitated by means of using this parameter. This parameter h¯rad is called the average pseudo-radiative heat transfer coefficient.

The burning time of iron particle increases quadratically with increasing the iron particle diameter. This observation can be deduced from both analytical and experimental results. On the other hand, Because of temperature dependency of mass diffusivity of oxygen in air (DO2-∞∝T∞3/2) and density of air (ρ∞∝T∞-1), iron particle burning time decreases with increasing the temperature of the gaseous oxidizing medium (tbdiff∝(ρ∞DO2-∞)-1∝T∞-1/2).

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work is supported by the Iran University of Science and Technology. But, this work has not been funded by any sources of financial support.
